Diary 11/14/2024

Didn't Need It vs Didn’t Have It (Emo Diary)

Recently, I started playing one of my old games called “Age Of Ape.” It's a fun game to play, not gonna lie. I've been playing it for 2 days now, and I feel happy when I'm playing. However, I feel like I'm escaping the truth, escaping reality, when I play video games. I stay up late, and I can feel my strength decreasing. I don't have the motivation to keep running on the treadmill. I feel like this will actually mess up my life if I keep playing it. So, I decided to cool down and write this diary to reflect on why and how I can deal with this issue.

I'll begin by explaining why people enjoy video games. Some may say, “Because I want to relax.” Some may say, “Because I want to make new friends.” However, almost all the players I've met in video games have challenging and uncontrollable real lives, and they need a safe way to escape those bad things happening in reality.

A recent example: I was raiding someone in the game, and that player became mad and started saying toxic things to me. I was confused and still debating with him, asking why he did that, but he continued to get mad at me. Eventually, I stopped the chat and said, “Maybe I misunderstood your words; I still believe you're a nice guy in real life.” Then he stopped and talked about his life in direct messages. He said he quit his job and is working in his family business now. “It is the end of my road,” he said. At that moment, I felt sorry because I know everyone may have a hard time in real life. They're just finding happiness online, so why am I still trying to break it down?

Coming back to myself, I started to ask myself why I play video games. I found out that it's for the exact same reason: I want to escape the issues I'm facing in real life. What issues am I facing? A lot, to be honest. Coming back to the title: Didn’t Need It vs Didn’t Have It. I feel very weak right now. I know I should be grateful for everything I have, but humans are always greedy and want more. When I see lots of great things, I ask myself, “Why don't I have that?” “Why don't I have that skill set?” “Why don't I have six-pack abs?” “Why can't I get that opportunity?” “Why can't I get a girlfriend?” I used to think, “I just don't need it.” However, this thought is wrong. How do I know I don't need it if I haven't even had it once? I keep improving in different areas, but the process of knowing that you are fat, ugly, weak, and worse than others is really tough, not gonna lie. It feels like I'm playing a losing battle. It feels like you can control the stuff around you when you try to control it.

So, what do I aim to get? The choices. The choices to choose. The choices to pick.

entry.title: Diary-11/11/2024
entry.content:
# Date: 2024-11-11

# First Diary

# Introduction

Since I feel like no one will see this website, I want to share something from the bottom of my heart. (If you see this diary, hope you have a nice day!) Maybe in the future when I look back, I will laugh at my words lol.

# How I am Right Now

I have improved some aspects of myself but found some weaknesses that I need to face right now.

# Two Main Physical Improvements:

  1. Better Skin Quality

    • In the past, I had tons of acne on my face. It made me feel terrible. I was extremely insecure about it. I felt afraid and sad when I looked in the mirror. No cap lol. I tried different retinoic acid (A 酸) products but they didn't work. However, deep down, I knew I could deal with this problem soon. I kept researching and developed better habits, such as drinking more water and changing the pillow cover (枕頭套) every 3 days. The main change was discovering different kinds of retinoic acid. I used to use benzoyl peroxide (which didn’t work well and made my face burn), then I switched to Tretinoin cream. It worked really well. After that, my skin started getting better day by day :>

  2. Cutting My Weight

    • When I was 82kgs, I didn’t know I was fat. I know it sounds dumb, lol. However, I didn’t realize it until I asked my little brother, "Hey, am I actually fat?" He said, "Yeah!" It was a shock for me, and he took a photo of me. That moment made me feel like I messed up my life. So, I started losing weight. I'm still losing weight but I need to control the speed of weight loss because losing weight too quickly can result in losing muscle. Let's see the result later on. Maybe I'll post the result of my first cut at the end of December on Instagram. :>

# The Issue I Need to Face:

  1. Bad at Communicating with Others
    • I feel comfortable when I'm alone but it feels like it's the only choice for me. I'm still thinking about how to solve this issue. Every time I see someone having a good time with their friends, I feel sad. This feeling is weird. I'm not jealous, but I know I’m weak in that part. The good thing is that in my daily life, I meet lots of nice people 😛 and deep down, I know I will solve this problem :>

# Conclusion

I like the quote, "You become what you think." Hope you all who read this far have a nice day :p

# The Complete Guide to Creatine: Benefits, Usage, and Safety

Date: November 9, 2024

# Introduction

Supp guys! I find out that creatine is a great supplement to have while working hard in gym. Thats why I want to write this blog about it. Creatine is one of the most popular and well-researched supplements in the fitness world. Whether you're an athlete, bodybuilder, or just looking to improve your workout performance, creatine can offer numerous benefits. In this blog, we'll explore what creatine is, how it works, its benefits, proper usage, and safety considerations.

# What is Creatine?

Creatine is a naturally occurring compound found in small amounts in certain foods and synthesized by the body. It is primarily stored in muscle cells, where it helps produce energy during high-intensity activities.

# How Does Creatine Work?

Creatine enhances the production of adenosine triphosphate (ATP), the primary energy carrier in cells. During intense exercise, ATP is rapidly depleted. Creatine phosphate donates a phosphate group to ADP, regenerating ATP and allowing for sustained energy production.

# Benefits of Creatine

Creatine offers a wide range of benefits for both athletes and non-athletes:

  1. Increased Muscle Mass:

    • Studies have shown that creatine supplementation can lead to an increase in muscle mass by up to 8% over periods ranging from 5 to 12 weeks.
    • For example, a study published in the Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research found that participants who supplemented with creatine gained an average of 2.2 kg (4.85 lbs) of muscle mass over 12 weeks.

  2. Enhanced Strength and Power:

    • Research indicates that creatine can improve maximum power/strength by 5-15%.
    • In a study by the International Society of Sports Nutrition, athletes experienced a 20% increase in strength in high-intensity activities such as weightlifting.

  3. Improved Exercise Performance:

    • Creatine has been shown to increase exercise performance by 10-20% in various sports and physical activities.
    • For example, sprint performance improved by 8% and the number of overall work repetitions increased by 14% in a study published in the Journal of Applied Physiology.

  4. Faster Recovery:

    • Creatine supplementation has been found to reduce muscle cell damage and inflammation, leading to faster recovery times. Athletes reported a 30% decrease in muscle soreness and improved muscle recovery after intense workouts.

  5. Cognitive Benefits:

    • Emerging research suggests that creatine might have cognitive benefits. A study published in the journal Psychopharmacology found that participants who took creatine experienced a 20% improvement in memory and intelligence test scores.

# How to Use Creatine

# Dosage and Timing

  1. Loading Phase: Some people choose to start with a loading phase, which involves taking 20 grams of creatine per day (split into 4 doses) for 5-7 days. This saturates the muscles with creatine quickly.
  2. Maintenance Phase: After loading, a maintenance dose of 3-5 grams per day is sufficient to maintain elevated creatine levels.
  3. Timing: Creatine can be taken at any time of the day, but it's often recommended to take it post-workout when your muscles are more receptive to nutrient uptake.

# Types of Creatine

  • Creatine Monohydrate: The most studied and effective form of creatine.
  • Micronized Creatine: Creatine monohydrate that has been processed into smaller particles for better solubility.
  • Creatine HCl: A form of creatine bonded with hydrochloric acid for improved absorption.

# Safety and Side Effects

Creatine is generally considered safe for most people when taken at recommended doses. However, some users may experience minor side effects, including:

  • Water Retention: Creatine can cause muscles to retain water, which may lead to temporary weight gain.
  • Digestive Issues: Some people experience stomach discomfort or bloating.
  • Muscle Cramping: Although rare, some users report muscle cramping.

# Who Should Avoid Creatine?

  • Individuals with kidney issues or impaired renal function should avoid creatine or consult a healthcare professional before use.
  • Pregnant or breastfeeding women should also avoid creatine supplementation.

# Conclusion

Creatine is a powerful supplement that can enhance muscle growth, strength, and overall exercise performance. By understanding how to properly use creatine and being aware of potential side effects, you can safely incorporate it into your fitness routine to achieve your goals.

Feel free to reach out if you have any questions or need further information. Happy lifting!
